title: Computing in UK Schools
segmentation: Thank you very much for that introduction, Andre and greetings to the Slovenian Academy from the Royal Society of London.
I'm very happy to be here to tell you about our experiences in the UK of attempting to transform the computing curriculum in schools.
I do not speak Slovenian.
I have no idea what's being said.
Earlier today, so I will just carry on and give you my story so.
In the UK, the Royal Society has conducted two studies of computing in schools.
And produce 2 reports and my talk is structured around these two reports, so I'm going to start.
With the first report, that was the result of a study conducted just over five years ago, and the report was called shut down or restart.
This was the title is supposed to suggest that computing in schools either needs to stop or needs to make and you start and go in some new directions, the.
The background to this report was an increasing feeling across universities and also industry that computing education in many UK schools was not satisfactory.
There were.
Several reports that came out at about the same time from Ofsted, which is the body that overseas teaching in UK schools.

the Royal Academy of Engineering, which is a partner Academy to the Royal Society Nestor, which looks after industries such as the Computer games industry and the Computer games industry, was very concerned about how teaching was going in UK schools.

At the same time, the universities were seeing significant falls in the number of students applying for University courses in computer science, and this corresponded to reductions in the numbers of pupils wanting to take the relevant qualifications at school.
So interest in schools in computing was falling in a very worrying way when of course demand for computing graduates.
From industry was rising, so the job prospects for computer science graduates were very good, but the number of people wanting to study computer science was falling rapidly.
And there was significant concern that this decline in interest in computer science.
Was going to damage the UK economy overtime because of this increasing requirement for computer scientists in industry.
The Royal Society gathered a meeting of stakeholders.
These were people from industry, from schools from universities, and we sat around a table in a room and discussed the situation and what impressed the Royal Society was.
The total consensus around the table that there was a problem and that something had to change in order to improve this position.
And so this led to the launch of a Royal Society study, and this study had an advisory group which I was asked to chair.
So the work I'm describing was not.
Just my work, in fact.
Mainly it was the work of others.
I simply had a chairing role in overseeing the study and the report that emerged.
Here are some of the numbers that were causing concern in the UK at that time.
The schools taught a subject which was called ICT Information and Communication Technologies and.
ICT was mainly about the use of computers.
So people taking ICT learned about office applications.
They learned about spreadsheets presentations but they learned essentially nothing about how the machines worked and how these applications were supported by the technology.
The GCSE in the UK is a national public examination taken by pupils, normally at age 16, so these are 16 year old pupils and what you see here is the numbers taking the ICT.
GCSE dropping very rapidly over the years from 2005 to 2010.
Here we are showing various forms of ICT GCSE but the trend is the same in all cases.

At the more advanced level in the UK, A levels are taken by pupils at age 18, so this is the final national exam that pupils take before they leave school and move onto college or University or into work.
And again, the story is the same.
The ICT and computing A levels were showing a significant fall in interest from pupils at school.
Part of the problem was down to the fact that schools were short of suitably qualified teachers.
There were exceptions, of course.

There were many examples of excellent teaching where schools were doing very well, but these were in a minority, and for the majority of pupils going to school in the UK, the teaching the teachers were not enthusiastic about computing and the subject that was offered was not a great interest.
And in the UK, if teenagers don't like something, they say it's boring.
OK, I don't know what the Slovenian equivalent is, but this is a standard if your teenage child doesn't want to do what you ask them to do, they say it's boring.
OK, not interesting.
As I say, there were exceptions and a lot of these exceptions were were coming through a grassroots movement.

The teachers themselves who were keen on computing started a movement called Computing at School CS or casts, and this grassroots movement was growing very strongly and the schools that engaged in this grassroots movement were doing well.
But again, there were far too few of them.
They were in maybe 10% of schools.
So.

The report came up with some recommendations and the first recommendation was that the government should set recruitment targets and actually provide financial incentives for people to train to teach computing at schools.
And.
They needed to be professional development for the teachers who were already in place to help them improve their subject knowledge and improve the standard of their teaching.
But perhaps the most fundamental concern was with the ICT curriculum itself.
This curriculum lumped many different topics together under one umbrella, and this led to a lot of confusion about what computing was about and.
This.
It allowed a great variety of teaching, but this this allowed schools to go to the lowest common denominator.
If you like to teach the simplest aspects and thereby satisfy the requirements of the curriculum.
And.
Just before we published this first report.
In fact, I think it was the day before the report was launched.
The Minister for Education at that time, Gove.
Recognize the problem and announced a review of the curriculum.
Now this was not a coincidence.

The government was well aware of the report it had been developed in consultation with the Department for Education, so the minister knew exactly what we were going to say on the Friday of that week and he made his grand announcement on the Thursday.
Thereby showing that the government was acting even ahead of the recommendations.
The recommendation we produced in the report was that the curriculum should clearly distinguish three aspects of computing, and I think I saw these on the screen earlier.
Bits of English on the slides.
And these three strands were digital literacy, which is the general ability to use computers safely.
Computer science, which is understanding the fundamental principles of computing and information technology, which is the applications of computing in industry and Commerce, and.
By defining these three aspects, we felt we could separate out the subjects that were being confused under ICT.
And we produced a picture.

We decided that to recommend that the ICT term should be dropped and digital literacy was a subject that should be taught to all pupils because everyone is going to be using computers in their future career, whether they're a computer scientist, a physicist, or working in business or Commerce teaching or keeping shops, everybody is going to use computers, so they need to know how to do it safely.
But there should also be the opportunity for those who are interested to study the subject more deeply in either the direction of computer science.
Or in the direction of information technology, or possibly both.

So we really wanted the subject separating out into those three strands, with digital literacy being for everyone and then the specializations being available to everyone, but not necessarily everyone doing them.
The.

Another problem that was related to the issue was the status of computing schools was finding it difficult to teach computing satisfactorily, and they were seeing it as a minor subject which if they had problems they could ignore.
Quite often you'd find the teacher teaching the ICT class was a teacher trained in geography who didn't have quite enough geography classes, and so they taught some ICT classes.
Or some other subject.
And this was because computing had a low status and school management didn't take it seriously.

And we felt very strongly that computer science had developed to the point that it should be viewed as a rigorous academic discipline, so it should be seen as an academic subject at the same level as maths, physics, chemistry, the other Sciences that should not be treated as a minority interest.
And.
It's very difficult to persuade school senior management to come round to this perspective.
We're still not there yet, but we still think this is an important objective.
And we think that there are strong economic and educational arguments for their speakers.
Computer science has introduced new ways of thinking about the world and under the heading of computational thinking.
You can look at many aspects of the world you can look at.
For example, the role of DNA in biology and see it as an information communication mechanism.
And if you understand how to think about information and how it's processed.
This gives you insights into all into many areas of life, not just computers themselves, so we wanted this to come through strongly.
We felt that by the end of their school.
Every child should be digitally literate.
They should know how to use computers safely.
They should have the opportunity to learn the deeper concepts in computer science and information technology, and clearly in the UK it's the responsibility of the Department for Education.
The DfE to establish the schemes of work and set the national curriculum.
We also felt there was a need for more rigorous qualifications than those that were existed at the time.
Universities in the UK have always been a bit unenthusiastic about computer science a lot.
The computing, a level and ICT even more so.
So I work in a computer science Department at Manchester and our admissions requirements are you have to have strong mathematics.
OK, that you're a level.
Mathematics has to be good.
Computer science, a level or computing A level ICT count, but that's not a prerequisite.

The prerequisite is strong mathematics, and this is because those other A levels in the computing area were not rigorous enough to really give us the information we needed to judge whether pupils who are applying to come to us had the necessary background to be able to cope with our courses.

And then we felt very strongly that the computer science and information technology GCSE's should be as an appropriate standard and they should have appropriate rigorous assessment methods that too much of the current GCSE's were about office applications and producing screenshots as a method of evaluation.
And we felt this was not rigorous enough.

There were some background concerns as well.

Lots of schools made excuses about their computing teaching because they were worried about network security, and you'll know that maintaining secure networks is a very complex issue if you're at all involved in this.
I'll recommendation was that schools should be held this should.
This should not be an obstacle to computing education.
There should be some kind of guide published that advised schools on how to set up networks that could both support flexible computing teaching and also provide the level of security they required.
Quite a lot of what was working well in some schools in the UK was outside the curriculum and there were many examples of exciting computer clubs, invited speakers coming into schools, and so on.
All of these were adding significantly to the exposure.
Pupils got to computing information and we felt this this was important.
We didn't wish to discourage this.
This should be.
Continued and enhanced.
We also looked outside the UK to see what was happening in other parts of the world.
And what we saw was that in most countries of the world similar problems were being faced.
Some countries we thought had started addressing these problems ahead of the UK and we thought they were good examples in Israel, NZ, Germany, India and to some extent in the USA.
Israel had taken a major review in 1990s and had a rigorous computer science high school program, which we thought was a good example.
And Germany in 2008 had adopted new standards that clearly made the distinction between ICT and computing education.
South Korea had done some interesting work on the high school curriculum and they got computer science in there and their proposed curriculum.
Remember, we're back in 2010 to 12 that proposed curriculum for 2013 included more fundamental concepts.
So we saw some good things happening.
But we also saw that many other countries were sharing similar difficulties to the UK.
So the key recommendations that came out of the report was that we required more specialist teachers in the UK and that will be a combination of recruiting more teachers and.

Improving the training for those who were already in place and we recommended this restructuring of the curriculum to distinguish the three areas of digital literacy, which was for everybody and opportunities to study computer science and information technology.
So.
This was produced by assembling a panel of experts.
This was the Advisory Board that I chaired and the project lasted 18 months.
We have public calls for evidence which produced responses from over 120 people in schools and universities and organisations and so on.
We commissioned research.

In other words, we paid research bodies to carry out specific research looking into issues such as international curricula and teachers supply, and we had various stakeholder engagement meetings and the stakeholders were people such as industry that employs computer science graduates.
Universities, schools and so on.
And the Royal Society made its input into the National Curriculum Review process.
The advisors who came in to help us.
Some of them are listed here.
the Royal Academy of Engineering I've mentioned IBM, Google, Microsoft are all active in the UK with quite a large number of employees.
E scales is a is a national body that looks after training for the computing industry.
The British Computer Society is the professional body in the UK with particular responsibility for computing issues and then schoolteachers.
And.
University staff and teacher training staff and so on were all brought in to do this.
And if you like the headline, if you like the the news headline, was that what we thought ICT was doing?
Was training pupils to be users of technology and we strongly wanted UK pupils to be created, not just users of technology.
So we wanted them to have the opportunity to understand enough technical detail that if they wish to follow a career in creating technology they could do so.
The outcome of this process was the report that I showed you earlier.
It was published in January 2012, the day before it was launched.
The Minister announced reforms to the curriculum.
The UK government.
Lots of politicians learn to say coding OK.

They don't understand computer science and, and indeed one of the problems that ensued was they they simplified the whole issue down to this word coding, and so now in the curriculum that was eventually introduced in September 2014.
Aspects of coding are introduced right from the beginning of primary education, so pupils at primary schools, which in the UK are from sort of five to 11.

They are doing coding exercises in school, not, you know, not writing sophisticated high level language, but using tools such as scratch from MIT, which is a graphical way of assembling sequences of instructions and building things that look like programs.
But don't actually require you to type any code into a machine.
And so coding has got into the system, but sadly that's about all they seem to have understood about computer science and.
There's a lot more to it than that.
Anyway, the curriculum change came in in the 2014 academic year and.
The Royal Society decided to have a follow on study to see how well the new curriculum was going.
This started in 2016 when the new curriculum had been running for two years and the report was published.
It's now December, isn't it?
So last month in November this year and the report is called after the reboot.
So you see, shut down or restart.
Clearly the government opted for restart and so this report is talking about what has happened since the curriculum was rebooted and these reports, by the way, are all public.
They're available on the Royal Society website.
The URL at the bottom.
This slide shows where you can find them and.
Not only are the reports available on those web pages, but all the supporting data that went into generating them is there too that the report itself is 135 pages long or something.
The supporting data is even bigger.
So.
So.
This was the.
Background and aims of this new project to look into how the curriculum change was going.
The background of course started with the previous report and.
What we found was.

The background of that report was the dwindling interest, and we made a number of recommendations, so now that the curriculum change had gone through the aims of the new project were to review the impact of computing education.
See to what extent the recommendations of the previous report had been followed through and how well they had been implemented and we were exploring how well progress had been made.
We gathered a lot of evidence in this second report phase.
There was a survey put out across all UK schools and 945 teachers responded 297 from primary schools and 526 from secondary schools.
We also commissioned case studies.
And we get detailed analysis of uptake patterns of the new qualifications framework.
And commissioned literature reviews.

One area that concerned us was the extent to which the pedagogy how computer science is taught has been researched and understood, and what you see is if you read the report is that there's been much less academic study of how to teach computer science to school pupils.
Then there has been of more established subjects such as maths and physics.
So we need more academic research into what are the most effective ways.
Of teaching computing subjects at school.
If we look at the uptake of the qualifications, this is a rather complicated set of data.
But what it's showing is over a series of years starting from 2012.
The number of pupils taking GCSE.
That's the age 16 national qualification in computing, and you can see that growing up to 2017.
You see it's still a quarter the size of history.
History is being established for a long time.
But if you consider the relative industrial importance of computing versus history, these numbers look odd.
Geography is a similar level to history business studies.
And it's been growing.
Mathematics, of course, is pretty much a compulsory subject at this stage in UK schools.
And so you see the role about.
Half a million pupils taking the mathematics GCSE every year and just over a 10th.
That number are taking computing.
And so one of the recommendations of this second report is that this uptake at key Stage 4 needs to be improved.
We found that 70% of pupils attend a school where this GCSE is offered, which means 30% go to a school where they don't even have the option of taking this GCSE.

It's not offered at all but only 11% of pupils actually take it up at this stage and the take up is correlated with mathematical ability that's similar to the fact that we use maths as an entry criterion.
There's a strong correlation.
Between pupils ability to.
Do computing computer science in particular, and their ability to handle maths.
And although ICT is being phased out that phase out is is being staged and 69 thousand of the pupils were still taking that GCSE.

And the recommendation emerging from this was that various bodies the learned societies should establish a curriculum committee to oversee how the curriculum developed and give advice on developing pathways.
And.
You'll notice here that I've not mentioned information technology.
This was essentially ignored as part of the new curriculum.

Computer science is established as an option, but information technology has disappeared from the recommendations of the original report, and that's something that needs to be revisited because it's clear that computer science, in its technical sense, is not a subject for everybody and information technology has an appeal to a different set of pupils.
And that should not be ignored.
And we also recommended that school governors and Ofsted, the body that overseas education should monitor how schools are teaching computing across the curriculum to all of their pupils.
An unintended consequence of this switch from ICT to computer science at GCSE.
Has been very bad impact on the gender balance.
Again, this may relate to the way computer science is taught as a fairly technical subject.
But for whatever reason.
ICT had about a 40% female participation.
The new computer science curriculum has about a 20% female participation.
This is a very serious problem and this is something that is concerning as a lot at the moment you see mathematics is about 5050.
If computing is like mathematics, why is the female participation so different?
Physics and chemistry are also 5050, so there's a real problem here.
We've had a gender balance problem in UK universities for a long time.
In my Department, our undergraduate intake is now about 25% female.
That's an increase over recent years, and the reason that we've seen this increase, we think, is because we recruit a lot of undergraduates from Central Europe, in particular from Romania.
And in Romania.

The female participation in computing is much higher than in the UK, so by recruiting from Eastern Europe or female participation appears to improve, it doesn't reflect an improvement in the UK schools position, which is a source of great concern.
The gender imbalance in computing the female uptake is the lowest of all of the STEM subjects.
Say level it's dropped to 10%, which is very low GCSE, it's poor.
Including computing as a course subject for all pupils at primary school may help this.
But mathematics and physics are still gender skewed, despite being part of the primary curriculum for a long time.

One of the things you observe if you change schools curriculum if you think about it, if it's changed throughout the schooling, it takes more than 10 years for the change to really settle down, because pupils who.
Start school at 5:00 and go into the new curriculum.
Will only get through the process so you only see the process all the way through after they've been at school for more than a decade.
So there are quite long time constants in really understanding these consequences.
One of the observations that we heard from the Institute of Physics who've done a very detailed study of gender in physics in the UK.

It is that observation is the great majority of primary school teachers in the UK or female arts graduates OK and female arts graduates may well give sort of adverse role model messages to their female pupils that maths and computing a hard.
Girls do arts, and we're not sure.
I mean, we're still looking into this process, but there's something very fundamental going on because there's no reason why computing and computer science should be male dominated.
As Andre said earlier, the first computer programmer was female and Ada Lovelace.
So we were really very concerned about gender balance and we think action is required.
It's a very tough issue.
People have tried addressing gender balance things and they seem to be deeply culturally set and so there's nothing.
Impossible about it because different countries have very different balances.
But once the culture begins to say that computing is a male subject, it's very difficult to turn that message around.
And.
We want more research.
We recommended that more research on pedagogy how computer science is taught, and curriculum development in computing should look very hard.
That's how to improve female participation.

Teacher supply is and continues to be a major problem and one piece of evidence here is if you look at the proportion of graduates leaving University who go into teaching, and in the Biological Sciences 20% of graduates from University going to teaching in mathematics and physics, it's about 10 or 12%.
In computing, is 5% in engineering it's lower, but of course engineering is not established as a school subject.
In the UK, computing is now established and therefore we would expect the percentage of graduates going into computing to be more like mathematics.
In other words, twice the number that we're seeing at the moment.
And we need to put things in place to encourage graduates to consider school teaching as a career.
Of course, one of the disadvantages is that in the UK, as in most of the world, teachers are relatively poorly paid compared with industry and in computing.
At the moment there are formidable salaries on offer from the big technology companies, the likes of of Google and Amazon are not only.
Attracting people away from school teaching.
They're attracting people out of universities in very large numbers as well.
So universities are finding that their pay scales are not competitive compared with what industry is offering.
There's an undersupply of qualified teachers.
The government set targets for recruiting teachers into computing and only 68% of this target was met, so they're only recruiting 2/3 of the number of teachers that they aim to teach.
And there are various detailed recommendations for how we might address this.
Including of course offering incentives, offering conversion courses so people can switch from another subject to computing and various modes of accreditation.
Doing more to support teachers already in position and exploring one called braided careers, which at which are opportunities for people to have a career which is divided between industry in school.

This seems to be quite attractive to some people in industry to spend one or two days a week teaching in a school and it's in the interest of the employers to allow some of their employees to do this because otherwise they won't find the recruits they need coming out of schools and universities.
The amount of time that teachers responsible for teaching computing are spending on CPD which is continued professional development.

I training is worryingly low and in our survey of teachers we discovered that a quarter of teachers do no in service training at all and the number who spend significant hours is very low indeed and this was based on 600 respondents.
It's very difficult for a school if it's if it's short of computing teachers to give teachers time off to do training.

The schools then have to pay for other teachers to stand in the schools in the UK are very tight in budgetary terms, so for any teacher to get time off for training is difficult, but training is absolutely necessary because computing is a new subject.
The Curriculum's only been in place two years.
If the teachers aren't trained.
They do not know how to cope with the new curriculum, so there's a.
Big tension there and opportunities for CPD this training need to be increased significantly.
And.
We recommended to government that there should be at least a 10 fold increase in the budget that they were spending on training for in service teachers.
And.
They were currently spending about 5 or £6,000,000 a year on teacher training.

We recommended it should be increased to 60 million, a tenfold increase and that would train the sort of numbers of teachers that we needed to solve the problem or to address the problem in the UK Now.

I don't know how far the UK budget announcements get followed in Slovenia, but ten days after we published the report, in fact, the Chancellor's budget speech was made in Parliament and he announced not 60 million that we asked for but 100 million for computer science in service training.

So again, this time the government didn't preempt the report by making an announcement the day before, but they did follow up the report with an announcement 10 days later, which was very encouraging.
And of course, again, they weren't responding to the report when it was published.
They knew what it was going to say a long time before it said it.
So this is going to be a big investment in training teachers in computing in the UK.
There are various working groups set up.
We need to see support go into schools so they can release staff to take advantage of this training.
If the training is available but the staff can't get a day or two off school, do take up the training then it won't be much use.
And we want more employer engagement in helping support teachers.
Again, perhaps not as much as releasing an employee for two days a week, but encouraging employees to go and support clubs in schools and so on.
We also need to do research into what is the best way to teach computing, because there's very little research available internationally.
So.
The upshot of all of that was the 2nd report after the reboot came out November the 12th.
I think, so less than a month ago.
It's available on the website.
It appears to have had very significant and rapid impact in terms of this budget announcement, but of course.
That is just one of the recommendations in the report.
There are many more and we will be watching carefully to see how many of those are followed up on.
So.
So thank you for listening.
That's my report from the UK.
